This field is set when is called by the patched to mirror the base game's implementation doing so.

member.summary: Contracts a class as capable of handling the following modded events:

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.Key
member.summary: The hotkey for the action in the resultant menu.
member.remarks: Where possible, it'll be highlighted in the string; otherwise, it will be to the left in typical "[h] hotkey" style.

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.Display
member.summary: How the action will be displayed in the resultant menu, with some caveats.
member.remarks: "Identify" with 'i' as the will display as "identify" due to the first instance of "I" being replaced with the hotkey, which is lower case, and highlighted.

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.Command
member.summary: The command sent in conjunction with an for handling parts to check that they are responding to the correct action.

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.PreferToHighlight
member.summary: A substring of which can be optionally specified, and the resultant menu will try first to find an appropriate character to replace with the .
member.remarks:
Tinkering Bytes uses this field for tinkering modifications:
When getting vendor actions for data disks, if the disk is for an item modification, the action has "mod an item with tinkering" assigned to , and 'T' assigned to .
This would show up in the menu as "mod an iTem with tinkering" if not for setting PreferToHighlight to "tinkering".
Set so, the result is the menu instead displaying "mod an item with Tinkering", where the "T" in "Tinkering" is the highlighted hotkey.

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.Default
member.summary: Used to determine which is the "selected by default" option in the resultant menu. Higher numbers supersede.

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.Priority
member.summary: How high up the list an action should be, where higher numbers indicate a higher position in the list.
member.remarks: "[l]ook" is Priority 10.

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.DramsCost
member.summary: A "simple" way of defining a drams cost that can be retrieved when an is fired.
member.remarks: This started as a way to quickly test passing arguments to the event, but removing it seemed pointless.

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.FireOnVendor
member.summary: , and , are used to determine which entity the action is supposed to it.
member.remarks:
will always fire first on if assigned a non- value, followed by, if their respective field is , the vendor, the item, and the player, in that order.
If multiple of these fieldss are set , then each indicated entity will get the opportunity to handle the event unless one of the prior handling entities returns false during their handling.

member.summary: , and , are used to determine which entity the action is supposed to it.
member.remarks:
will always fire first on if assigned a non- value, followed by, if their respective field is , the vendor, the item, and the player, in that order.
If multiple of these fieldss are set , then each indicated entity will get the opportunity to handle the event unless one of the prior handling entities returns false during their handling.

member.summary: , and , are used to determine which entity the action is supposed to it.

will always fire first on if assigned a non- value, followed by, if their respective field is , the vendor, the item, and the player, in that order.
If multiple of these fieldss are set , then each indicated entity will get the opportunity to handle the event unless one of the prior handling entities returns false during their handling.

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.FireOn
member.summary: An arbitrary entity that the action wants to an . If assigned, this entity is always fired on first.
member.remarks:
It needn't otherwise be part of the interaction at all, so steps should be taken to ensure that it's a valid target for handling the event (for example, not a cached object).
A use case for this is having whoever "owns" the given item handle by assigning E.Item.InInventory to it during .

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.ProcessAfterAwait
member.summary: The main method patched to divert to this mod's implementation of vendor actions, , is and calls an method via .
member.remarks:
This is unfamiliar territory for me, so I've tread carefully and tried to mimic it as much as possible. Some of the base game's handling of vendor actions occurs once the has finished, so this field, set to , indicates that the action wants to be processed/handled after the has finished.
I believe that "doing an " inside an already "doing" is a great way to see your desktop, so I recommend setting this to if your custom action requires handling that, itself, wants to .
The base game's "Add to trade" action would require this field be set , as it normally happens after has run.

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.ProcessSecondAfterAwait
member.summary: Indicates that, for an action that requires a second firing of , irrespective of the first firing occurring during 's or after it, the second one should occur once has finished.
member.remarks:
Any action that fires its first time after will always fire its second time after too, if a second firing is flagged for.
See for more information on , its , and how vendor actions interract with it.

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.ClearAndSetUpTradeUI
member.summary: Indicates whether or not the active instance of should call after the action has been processed.
member.remarks:
Actions that affect the contents of the trade UI ought to assign this , so that each handling of an action gets a refreshed UI with any changes reflected.
The base game's "Identify" and "Repair" actions would require this field be set .

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.Staggered
member.summary: Indicates whether or not an action should call twice as part of the action being resolved.
member.remarks:
The main purpose of this field is to allow for the closure of the trade window "during" the "handling" of vendor actions, without the UI being manipulated while is resolving.
Tinkering Bytes requires this field be set for UD_VendorDisassembly:
The "invoice" for disassembly is calculated and presented to the player during 's .
- If they accept, the trade window is closed and disassembly begins as a "joint" between the player and the trader.
- If they don't (or can't) accept the invoice, then closure of the trade window and the second firing are cancelled.

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.CloseTradeBeforeProcessingSecond
member.summary: If , indicates that the trade window should be closed before is called the second time.
member.remarks:
It is recommended (by LibrarianMage/Books, whose modding advice is invaluable) that the trade UI not be manipulated while any are being resolved.
It's my recommendation that this, or , be the only means by which the trade UI is manipulated when dealing with vendor actions.

member.name: F:UD_Vendor_Actions.UD_VendorAction.CloseTradeAfterProcessing
member.summary: Indicates that the trade window should be closed at the end of a given action being resolved.
member.remarks:
If the chosen action has this field set to , the trade window will be closed once the action is processed, whether successfully handled or not.
It is recommended (by LibrarianMage/Books, whose modding advice is invaluable) that the trade UI not be manipulated while any are being resolved.
It's my recommendation that this, or , be the only means by which the trade UI is manipulated when dealing with vendor actions.

This is typically the 's .
Indicates whether or not should be called once control leaves the method (which is after any events have been resolved).

if none of the handling entities returns after their ;
otherwise.

member.summary: This method shows a UI element with a processed list of vendor actions that can be selected from for handling by various different involved entities.
member.remarks: The code for this method was taken largely 1:1 from the decompiled base game's , altered only slightly to account for differences between the two systems.
member.param: An uprocessed dictionary containing keyed vendor actions.
The item for which the vendor actions are being listed and picked.
A short blurb appearing before the list of vendor actions.
The by which the final list will be sorted.
Currently unimplemented. Passed true if the TradeLine showing the menu was clicked.
member.returns:
The selected if one was picked;
otherwise.

member.param: The object to which the iterated will be attached, if not already present.
The derivative by which a is included or not for iteration over.

member.name: T:XRL.World.Parts.UD_TradeUI_DisplayItem
member.summary: Prevents a "display-only" pseudo-item's existence persisting longer than the duration of the trade it was created for.
member.remarks: Pseudo-items by their nature aren't "real" items and shouldn't have the opportunity to be interacted with outside of the trade UI. They're an abstraction of either inforamtion relevant to trading, such as the contents of a creature's bit locker, or of a service that a trader could provide that doesn't involve an item, involves an item yet to be picked, or involves an item yet to exist.

member.name: T:XRL.World.Parts.UD_VendorActionHandler
member.summary: Class designed to functionally restore the base game's vendor action behaviour that is otherwise skipped by the patches in this mod.
member.remarks:
Largely, the base game's vendor action handler methods are called directly for their respective vendor actions, and the conditions by which they're offered are, for all intents and purposes, the same.
See for the base game's implementation to compare.
